description: From Middle English bole, from Old Norse bolr, akin to Danish bul and German Bohle (“plank”). See also bulwark (“defensive wall”).

entries.meaning: The trunk or stem of a tree.
examples: Enormous elm-tree boles did stoop and lean / Upon the dusky brushwood underneath / Their broad curved branches, fledged with clearest green, / New from its silken sheath.

description: Ancient Greek βῶλος (bôlos, “clod or lump of earth”): compare French bol. Doublet of bolus.

entries.meaning: Any of several varieties of friable earthy clay, usually coloured red by iron oxide, and composed essentially of hydrous silicates of alumina, or more rarely of magnesia.
(colour) The shade of reddish brown which resembles this clay.

examples: […] or else […] the churches were very incurious to swallow such a bole, if no pretension could have been reasonably made for their justification.

entries.meaning: Alternative form of boll (old unit of measure).
(Scotland) An aperture with a shutter in the wall of a house, to admit air or light.
examples: "Open the bole," said the old woman firmly and hastily to her daughter-in-law, “open the bole wi' speed, that I may see if this be the right Lord Geraldin […] .
